message: Today, I was honored to take the oath of office to continue serving North Carolina's Fourth Congressional District, which now includes parts of Orange, Wake, and Durham Counties.

I was proud to stand with my colleagues Congresswoman Alma S. Adams and Congressman G. K. Butterfield in support of Governor Roy Cooper's proposal to expand Medicaid in North Carolina. This common-sense action will provide health care to over half a million North Carolinians, improve quality of care, create tens of thousands of jobs, and save the state hundreds of millions of dollars.  https://price.house.gov/press-releases/price-adams-butterfield-call-for-medicaid-expansion-in-nc/
Congresswoman Alma S. Adams, Congressman G. K. Butterfield, and I are fighting for the Affordable Care Act because we know how important it is to North Carolina families.

I spoke on the House Floor today in strong opposition to the Republican budget resolution that would add $9.5 trillion to the debt in order to pave the way for a repeal of the Affordable Care Act (ACA). I will continue to fight against any attempt to repeal the ACA, which would put tens of millions of Americans at risk of losing their health care coverage.
Great turnout at today's Raleigh rally to save our health care! We must fight to protect the Affordable Care Act for the millions of Americans who rely on it.

This year, as we celebrate the life of Martin Luther King Jr., we must renew our commitment to social justice and equality. In a time of hateful and divisive political rhetoric, Dr. King's example reminds us that we should treat our fellow Americans with respect and empathy, seeking understanding rather than giving into fear.
I released a statement about my difficult decision to attend the Inauguration despite my grave concerns about Donald Trump's appalling activity.

I am thrilled to join thousands of North Carolina women this morning as we make a stand for unity, equality, and inclusion. Honored to fight alongside millions of my fellow Americans to protect women's rights and build a better country.

I am deeply concerned that President Trump continues to spread misinformation about voter fraud in the 2016 election despite the fact that his false claims have been thoroughly debunked by credible, nonpartisan news organizations and academic experts. President Trump's reckless disregard for the truth damages our democracy.
It's not too late to sign up for 2017 coverage under the Affordable Care Act -- the deadline is January 31st. Visit healthcare.gov to learn more!
It's not too late to sign up for 2017 coverage under the Affordable Care Act -- the deadline is January 31st. Visit healthcare.gov to learn more!

I condemn in the strongest possible terms President Trump's shameful order on refugees, which flies in the face of our most deeply held democratic values. I have been outraged by many of Mr. Trump's comments on the campaign trail and his actions as president, but this executive order is especially horrifying. We must never forget that we are a nation of immigrants, founded as a refuge for the persecuted and oppressed. I will fight to ensure that our constitutional commitment to equality,  inclusion, and freedom of religion is protected against this unprecedented attack.

I have heard an outpouring of concern and outrage about the President's executive order, which violates our most basic constitutional principles. Over the coming days, I will take the following action. Tomorrow afternoon, I will meet with refugee families and organizations in Durham to discuss the impact on our local community. Tomorrow evening, I will join House and Senate leaders on the steps of the United States Supreme Court to call for the order to be repealed. As soon as Congress gavels back into session, I will also co-sponsor legislation to repeal it and defund its enforcement.  As a senior member of the House subcommittee responsible for immigration funding, I expect a thorough accounting from White House officials about the justification for and execution of President Trump's order, and I plan to hold the Trump Administration to account during the coming weeks.
NA

I hope you’ll join me this Saturday, February 4, for a community listening session at the Orange County Public Library in Hillsborough.    Feel free to drop by at any time between 2:00 and 3:30 p.m. to voice your concerns and have questions answered about the issues that are important to you.  My staff will be on hand to help you with any issues you may be having with federal government agencies. Hope to see you there!  Over the course of the next several weeks, I will be hosting a number of town halls and listening sessions throughout the Fourth District. You can  RSVP for the Hillsborough event here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/hillsborough-community-listening-session-tickets-31549217559

As a member of the House of Representatives, I do not have the opportunity to weigh in formally on President Trump’s appointments to executive branch positions. But as a former teacher and the son of educators, I feel compelled to share my concerns about Betsy DeVos, his nominee for Secretary of Education. In her confirmation hearings, Ms. DeVos failed to demonstrate that she is qualified to effectively advocate for public education and the best interests of all students and educators. Hundreds of Fourth District residents have called my office to voice similar concerns, and I join them in calling on the Senate to reject Ms. DeVos’s misguided nomination.

Due to the overwhelming response I have received from constituents interested in attending my Hillsborough community listening session this Saturday, I have decided to move the event to the Orange County Social Services Building at 113 Mayo Street. Doors will open at 1:45 PM, and space will be available on a first-come, first-served basis.  This will be the first in a series of community listening forums and town hall meetings I will be hosting throughout the Fourth District in the coming weeks, including events in Chapel Hill, Durham, Raleigh, and other communities in Wake County. If you are unable to join me on Saturday, I hope you will consider attending one of these future events. Details on these events will be available on my website and Facebook page in the coming days, or you can sign up for my e-newsletter to ensure you receive notice.  https://hillsboroughlisteningsession.eventbrite.com

This morning, I took a tour of the Durham-Orange Light Rail with Congressman Butterfield, Mayors Bell and Hemminger, and other elected and community officials from Orange, Durham, and Wake Counties. This project is a vitally important component of the Triangle's multi-modal transportation future.
I will be fighting to protect the EPA and many other vital federal investments!

Tonight's 9th Circuit decision reaffirms our conviction that America is enriched by the hardworking women and men who come from around the world to call our communities home. This victory demonstrates that even in these challenging times we are not helpless in the face of bigotry and xenophobia; we can and must fight back to protect the rights of our neighbors and defend our nation's bright promise.

General Flynn's resignation does not put to rest my grave concerns about the relationship between the Trump Administration and the Russian government. For the sake of our democracy, there must be a thorough independent investigation into Russian influence on President Trump and his advisers.

I want to hear from you about what I can do to better represent you in Washington. I hope you will join me for community listening sessions on Saturday, March 4 in Knightdale and South Durham.   Can't make it that day? I will also be hosting events in Raleigh, Garner, Chapel Hill, and Cary later in March.  RSVP: knightdalelisteningsession.eventbrite.com or durhamlisteningsession.eventbrite.com

Freedom of the press is at the foundation of our democracy. I condemn President Trump's adversarial attempts to undermine the ability of serious, credible journalists to report on his administration. The press is not the enemy -- it is a vital voice for the truth and for good governance.

I hope you will join me for town hall meetings in Cary, Raleigh, and Chapel Hill. As previously announced, I will also be hosting community listening sessions in Knightdale and Durham on March 4th.  Please RSVP at for each session on the appropriate Eventbrite page. More information about all of these events is available on my website at https://price.house.gov/blog/content/upcoming-town-halls-and-listening-sessions/.

This afternoon, I testified before my colleagues on the House Appropriations Committee to advocate for federal arts and humanities programs. The National Endowment for the Arts and National Endowment for the Humanities are vital cultural resources and support millions of jobs, and I will strongly oppose misguided attempts to eliminate their funding.  Read my full testimony at https://price.house.gov/speeches/price-testimony-supporting-the-arts-and-humanities/.

The evidence suggests that the Attorney General lied under oath; he should resign.   This controversy once again underscores that there must be a nonpartisan, independent investigation into possible collusion between President Trump’s campaign and Russia.
Join me and local safety organizations and first responders tomorrow afternoon at the Friday Center in Chapel Hill for a free Car Seat Safety Check from a certified technician!

Due to overwhelming interest, my town hall meeting in Cary tonight will be held at the Cary Arts Center, just a few doors down from our previously announced location. Seating will be first come, first served. Look forward to seeing you there!

Make no mistake: President Trump's rebranded #muslimban will still harm refugees and jeopardize our national security. I co-sponsored legislation to repeal the first executive order, and I will take similar action to oppose the latest version.
Had a wonderful Cary Town Hall this evening!
Like other products that carry his name, TrumpCare is not what it promises and would be harmful to consumers. I strongly oppose this proposal.

On this International Women's Day, I am more committed than ever to fighting for equal rights for women today and building a better future for the women of tomorrow. In the current Congress, I have co-sponsored legislation to guarantee fair and equal pay, to protect reproductive rights and funding for Planned Parenthood's vital women's health programs, and to support initiatives that provide life-saving assistance to women and girls around the world.
I strongly oppose President Trump's reported proposal to cut $6 billion from our nation's affordable housing programs. These programs are the foundation of economic empowerment.
Chapel Hill Town Hall
Chapel Hill Town Hall Part 2
Raleigh Town Hall

Some fast facts from the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office about TrumpCare, the Republicans' proposal to repeal the Affordable Care Act:  1) TrumpCare would take away health coverage from 24 million Americans by 2026.  2) TrumpCare would cause 7 million Americans to lose their employer-provided health plans.  3) TrumpCare would increase premiums by 24-29 percent on average over the next two years.  4) Older Americans would see their premiums increase by as much as 750 percent.  This proposal is terrible policy, and it demonstrates that President Trump and congressional Republicans care more about rewarding special interests than protecting the health and welfare of Americans.
I am outraged by President Trump's starvation budget. Here's why I will fight against this extreme proposal.
Happy World Poetry Day! This afternoon, I'm reading the great Langston Hughes and reflecting on our democracy.   https://www.poets.org/poetsorg/poem/let-america-be-america-again

I have been looking at the numbers for the Republican ACA repeal proposal, and it would be devastating for lower-income and older North Carolinians. You can read more on my website at https://price.house.gov/uploads/ACA%20Repeal%20NC-Wake%20Fact%20Sheet.pdf.
NA
I tallied up calls to my office about #TrumpCare, the disastrous Republican ACA repeal plan:  217 support Trumpcare 3298 oppose it  That's 93% opposed.

In case you missed it, I will be back in North Carolina tomorrow hosting a community listening session in Garner. I hope you will join me for this public event at Angie's Restaurant from 2:30 to 4 PM!  garnerlisteningsession.eventbrite.com
I have heard your calls and read your emails, and I am proud to stand with you in the fight to defend the vital protections of the #ACA.
Great to hear from constituents at my Garner Listening Session hosted at Angie's Restaurant. We'll be here until 3:30 pm if you're able to join us!
I am voting against S.J.Res.34 because I believe we must protect the privacy of American broadband consumers. #broadbandprivacy
I am taking action to support an independent investigation into the Trump campaign's alleged ties to Russia.

In 1963, Congress passed the Equal Pay Act. A half century later, women still make 80 cents for every dollar a man makes. It's time to pass the Paycheck Fairness Act, which would hold employers accountable for wage discrimination.
I strongly oppose President Trump's nomination of Neil Gorsuch to the Supreme Court, and I am alarmed by the unprecedented tactics Republicans are using to push through his confirmation.
Honored to host the 2017 Fourth District Congressional Art Competition for high school artists. Learn more on my website at http://bit.ly/2o10LK1.
Great turnout at my annual Fourth District Health Fair at Salvation Army HQ, 1863 Capital Boulevard in Raleigh. Stop by before 3 PM for free health services, screenings, and consultations!
No matter how the Republicans spin it, their ACA repeal plan would strip health care from millions of Americans. I remain strongly opposed any attempts to repeal the Affordable Care Act.

Today's deeply misguided executive order puts at risk North Carolina coastal areas and fisheries, which are among our most precious natural assets. President Trump seems to think that we have to endanger these coastlines and wild places to grow the economy, that energy development and environmental protection are somehow at odds. That's a dangerously outmoded way of thinking, one that disregards the concerns of dozens of coastal communities that have voiced bipartisan opposition to offshore drilling. This approach could also put us at a competitive disadvantage relative to those countries that are developing more sustainable energy solutions. If he's serious about creating jobs and building a stronger energy future, Mr. Trump should put the anti-environment bluster aside and commit to investing in renewable technologies and basic research.

Today, House Republicans are forcing through an ACA repeal with no CBO score and no hearings. Many Members haven't even had a chance to read the bill, which was only made public at 8 PM last night. If Speaker Ryan and President Trump want to take affordable health care away from tens of millions of Americans, they should at least have the courage to do so transparently.  https://twitter.com/RepDavidEPrice/status/860094156248555521
Why I Oppose TrumpCare
Happy National Teachers' Day! I spent some time this afternoon reading letters from some of my younger constituents.

Honored to host the 2017 Congressional Art Competition reception this evening. It was extraordinary to view the works of so many talented high school artists in the Fourth Congressional District.   This year's winner is Brooke Connolly of Cardinal Gibbons High School. Congratulations to all the participants!

President Trump's rash and unprecedented actions threaten the integrity of our democratic institutions and the credibility of ongoing investigations into his campaign's alleged ties to and collusion with Russia. Congress must immediately appoint a special prosecutor to ensure that we pursue this matter wherever the facts may lead.

Great visit to Hodge Road Elementary in Knightdale, a dual language immersion magnet program. We must prioritize foreign language education -- my bipartisan World Language Advancement and Readiness Act would support language immersion and other innovative programs.

Much like the poll taxes and literacy tests of the Jim Crow era, North Carolina’s shameful Voter ID law is nothing more than racial discrimination in the guise of voter protection. Rather than erecting unconstitutional barriers to participation in our democracy, the General Assembly should be making it easier for all eligible North Carolinians to make their voices heard at the ballot box.

Whatever President Trump's motivation for leaking intelligence to the Russians, his actions threaten the safety of members of the U.S. intelligence community, the lives of foreign intelligence assets, and our relationships with key allies. Such actions undermine the international community's efforts to degrade and destroy ISIS. We are clearly in uncharted territory -- the President has no respect for longstanding diplomatic norms or the grave responsibilities of his office, and his Administration is regularly misleading the American people. It’s time for my Republican colleagues to join Democrats in holding President Trump accountable for his actions.  A good place to start would be an independent investigation into the troubling allegations of collusion between Trump’s campaign and Russian officials.

The appointment of a special counsel is an important first step, and Director Mueller is a public servant of unimpeachable character. But as a DOJ official, he will still be answerable to President Trump. That's why I have joined fellow House Democrats in demanding a vote to create a fully independent commission to investigate the Trump campaign's ties to Russia.
Honored to receive a Defenders of Justice award from the NC Justice Center along with an amazing group of NC advocates and public officials.
We can only guarantee true equal protection for North Carolina voters by establishing an independent, non-partisan redistricting commission.

A budget is a moral document that says a great deal about the priorities and principles of the president proposing it. We shouldn't be surprised, then, that the Trump budget demonstrates the same lack of regard for vulnerable populations that has tainted his campaign and presidency.

Withdrawing from the Paris Climate Agreement would be an appallingly short sighted move by President Trump – one with potentially disastrous consequences for our country and the world. This move would jeopardize U.S. global leadership in the fight against climate change, while undermining the nation’s long-term economic competitiveness and national security. I urge him to remain in this agreement, and employ U.S. leadership to encourage the global community to combat this man-made climate crisis together.  The next generation is counting on us to take decisive action now.

Today's hearing was an important step toward getting the truth about the Trump campaign's alleged collusion with Russia's interference in the 2016 election. In light of Director Comey's testimony, we must redouble our efforts to ensure a thorough, transparent investigation into this deeply troubling and vitally important matter. To that end, I support the ongoing investigations by the U.S. Senate and Special Counsel Mueller, and I have also co-sponsored legislation to create an independent commission to conduct a separate inquiry.

The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office has found that Trumpcare would strip health care coverage from millions of Americans. But did you know that it would also cost North Carolina thousands of jobs? No wonder Republican Senators are plotting their repeal strategy behind closed doors with no hearings or public transparency.
Great work by the team from Southeast Raleigh Magnet School!

The mean-spirited and disingenuous Senate Republican ACA repeal proposal would strip health care from millions of Americans -- particularly low-income families and seniors --  in order to fund a tax break for the wealthy. It's no wonder this bill was negotiated in secret -- Senate Republicans cannot credibly claim to their constituents that this proposal will provide affordable coverage or improve quality of care. I remain open to improving and building on the progress of the Affordable Care Act, but I am strongly opposed to the Republican Trumpcare proposal that would jeopardize the health and well-being of my constituents.
LIVE NOW: Discussing the destructive nature of the latest Trumpcare proposal
I have serious concerns about the Trump Administration's policy at the United Nations.

Last week, I asked my constituents about the Affordable Care Act and Medicaid. These are just a few of the powerful stories I heard. In the coming days, I will be meeting directly with more patients, advocates, caregivers, and providers. The message is clear: we cannot allow the Senate Trumpcare bill to eliminate coverage for 22 million Americans.

Just wrapped up a health care roundtable with local advocates to hear how the Affordable Care Act has been lifesaving for many Triangle families, and the devastating impact the Republican's health care bill would have for individuals with disabilities and those with preexisting conditions. Here are a few of their stories.

Tonight, I will offer an appropriations amendment to ensure that no funding can be used by President Trump's alarming "Election Integrity" Commission to collect or store state and local voter data. You can watch the committee hearing live at 7 PM:  https://appropriations.house.gov/videos/
Appropriations season means late nights, but I am lucky to have the most talented staff on Capitol Hill. Here's proof:

Two years after the JCPOA’s adoption, the agreement remains our best means of preventing a nuclear-armed Iran. Rather than rashly abandoning the JCPOA as some Republicans have suggested, the United States must continue to work with our negotiating partners to hold the Iranian regime to the highest standards of monitoring and verification.

I continue to be alarmed by the Trump Administration’s incendiary rhetoric about immigrants and refugees.   During today's DHS Appropriations markup, I took action to hold President Trump accountable for his deeply misguided immigration policies. Trump's DHS is failing to humanely enforce our nation’s immigration laws without causing undue upheaval or collateral damage, leading to a surge in immigration arrests explicitly designed to tear communities apart.  Today, I offered an amendment to shift funding for these misguided enforcement activities to instead increase customs staffing at airports and ports of entry. Unfortunately, Republicans voted this reasonable proposal down. I will keep fighting to ensure that immigration enforcement prioritizes dangerous criminals rather than contributing members of society.

My offices in Washington & Raleigh are accepting applications from college students for our fall 2017 internship program. The deadline is Friday, July 28!  More here: https://priceforms.house.gov/constituent-services/internships-dc.htm

You may have heard that President Trump and Republicans are shamefully trying to undermine the credibility of the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO), which recently found that TrumpCare will strip health care coverage from between 24 and 32 million Americans.   What you might have missed is that some of those same Republicans are refusing to authorize 27 major VA medical facility leases across the country -- including one in Raleigh -- due to CBO scorekeeping. Why do House Republicans only ignore the CBO when it comes to taking away healthcare from millions of Americans?  I have cosponsored legislation that would authorize these major medical facilities and help NC veterans get access to the care they need. I have also sent letters to the CBO, the VA, and House Republicans to try to rectify this issue. #RepublicanHypocrisy
How dare President Trump question the bravery of transgender individuals who are willing to sacrifice their lives for our country. Courage transcends identity.

What's your best app idea? The 2017 Congressional App Challenge launches today for NC-04 students high school age or younger. Apps are due by noon on November 1.   More: https://price.house.gov/congressional-app-challenge/
Last call! Tomorrow is the deadline to apply for a Fall Internship in my Washington, DC or Raleigh offices.   Application → https://priceforms.house.gov/constituent-services/internships-dc.htm

I am pleased to announce that NC will receive an additional $32 million in Hurricane Matthew relief. This funding, which will prove vital to North Carolina’s recovery, is the result of bipartisan advocacy from the delegation and Governor Cooper.   Make no mistake, however: the new allocation still leaves us hundreds of millions of dollars short of the demonstrated need. Our delegation must continue to stress to the Administration and congressional leadership that many North Carolinians are living in the devastation wrought by Hurricane Matthew, and we will not stop fighting to get them the funding they deserve.

Our most deeply-held democratic values are under threat. Today, I introduced legislation offering common-sense reforms that would put regular citizens ahead of special interests and ensure that federal representatives--including the President--remain accountable to the people who elect them.  The We the People Act includes proposals to comprehensively reform campaign finance laws, restrict gerrymandering by supporting nonpartisan redistricting commissions, increase the number of eligible voters who vote by allowing same day registration, strengthen lobbying laws, and address integrity and transparency problems in the Executive Branch.  Learn more here: https://price.house.gov/press-releases/price-introduces-comprehensive-democracy-reform-legislation/

Great news for travelers! The Westgate Passport Facility is now open in Raleigh. It is the only location that accepts walk-in customers for passport processing in North Carolina's 4th Congressional District.   The Westgate Passport Facility is located at 1 Floretta Place in Raleigh. The hours of operation are Monday through Friday 10:15 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. and Saturday from 8:15 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.  If you prefer to make an appointment, you can call (919) 420-5343.
‪Celebrating #NationalNightOut with Durham residents and our law enforcement community. #NNO17 ‬

I often boast that the Research Triangle region is one of the most beautiful places in the country to live, work, & raise a family.  Perhaps you’ve had similar conversations with friends or family from out of town.  Well now we have a chance to back up our words: I am excited to invite you to participate in the first Fourth District Photo Contest.  To enter the contest, email your high resolution photo, full name, permanent address, and the location of the photo to NC04photos@mail.house.gov. Photos must be of a landmark, landscape, or cityscape in Wake, Durham or Orange Counties and cannot include images of people.   More information here: https://price.house.gov/4th-district-photo-contest/

Happy Birthday, President Barack Obama! From expanding health care coverage for millions of Americans to reviving a struggling economy - your vision & legacy continues to inspire a nation on our march to create a more perfect union.

Since the beginning of the year, I have held seven Community Listening Sessions throughout the Fourth District, joining more than 1,500 constituents at forums in Raleigh, Cary, Garner, Knightdale, Durham, Hillsborough, and Chapel Hill.  As Congress adjourns for its summer district work period, I hope you’ll join me at my next one, on Wednesday, August 23 in Raleigh at Laurel Hills Community Center from 6:00 - 7:30 p.m.   RSVP: NRaleighListeningSession.Eventbrite.com

President Trump’s rhetoric on North Korea reflects a dangerous brinkmanship that weakens, not strengthens, our national security and our alliances. The United States needs to stand with our allies to respond to the North Korea threat. Now more than ever, we need leadership and diplomacy from this administration, not amateurish saber-rattling.  http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/08/08/542299360/trump-says-u-s-will-meet-north-korean-threats-with-fire-and-fury

The display of hatred and bigotry we are seeing in Charlottesville, Virginia has no place in America. Make no mistake, these acts of violence and vitriol come from organized white supremacists. It is comforting to see the outpouring of condemnation and counter protests from Americans around the country. But until we see more than just vague tweets from our President, his silence will only help provide fuel for these acts of hatred.  http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/torch-wielding-white-supremacists-march-university-virginia-n792021

ICYMI: Senator Tom Udall and I introduced legislation to restore integrity, accountability, and transparency to our election system. The News & Observer is right, this is a "blueprint of how good government should work."  http://www.newsobserver.com/opinion/editorials/article166920552.html
Confronting hate: Reflections in the wake of Charlottesville
Celebrating today's #SolarEclipse2017 at The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill's Morehead Planetarium & Science Center! Let's continue this universal embrace of science!

What's the latest with health care? Join me & find out at this Saturday's health care town hall. The event will be held at Tarboro Road Community Center in Raleigh from 10:30 to noon. I hope to see you there!
Congressman Price Responds to President Trump’s Speech on Afghanistan
Join me today at 6:00pm on Facebook Live for the Raleigh Community Listening Session!

I just wrapped up my eighth Community Listening Session of the year in Raleigh, NC! We had a great discussion on healthcare, the budget, and many other important issues affecting my constituents and the American people. Check it out!

Inspired by the work of UNC Gillings School of Global Public Health. Their innovative research is helping to prevent the spread of global diseases like Zika, SARS, and MERS, while also being at the forefront of efforts to combat opioid abuse here at home.
Reps. Price and Connolly Call on Trump Administration to Stop Equivocating on Two-State Solution
Reminder! Send your best photos of the district by August 31 to NC04photos@mail.house.gov for a chance to be featured on price.house.gov.
Congressman Gerry Connolly and I issued a statement this morning regarding the Trump Administration's equivocation on a two-state solution. Check out our joint statement here: http://bit.ly/2wuTrOo

President Trump's pardon of Joe Arpaio represents a complete disregard for rule of law and a lack of respect for minority communities. Make no mistake, Sheriff Arpaio is a birther, a racist, and a shame to his profession. This is the company that our President keeps.  https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2017/08/25/trump-pardons-controversial-former-arizona-sheriff-joe-arpaio/

Today I checked-in on the progress at downtown Raleigh’s Union Station, a multi-modal transportation center scheduled to open in early 2018. Thanks to vital federal TIGER grant funding, this project will improve transportation options for Triangle residents by providing rail, as well local and regional bus options all in one location.  With the growth in Wake County and the greater Triangle area, we must continue to invest in transportation and plan for future growth in our state. https://goo.gl/REbwMt

As Americans, we don't get to choose our history, but we do get to choose the history we wish to honor. That's why I am calling on the North Carolina General Assembly to repeal the state law that strips communities of their right to remove monuments they deem hateful or discriminatory.   http://wncn.com/2017/08/30/congressman-joins-calls-to-remove-uncs-silent-sam/

It is reprehensible that President Trump is considering actions that would pull the rug out from under 800,000 DREAMers. DREAMers are a representation of the American story. As children, they were brought to the United States by parents who wished to give them a brighter future. They are our neighbors, our classmates, and members of our armed services. They contribute to the well-being of our nation and our economy and as proud member of the House Democrats, I will stand with them. #DefendDACA

This Labor Day, I'm fighting for a #BetterDeal for American workers. That means providing good jobs with good wages, training for 21st century jobs, equal pay for equal work, reliable retirement, and decreasing the cost of health care. To make our economy work for all Americans, we need to tilt the power back in the hands of working people.

President Trump’s shameful decision to rescind the DACA program puts the futures of 800,000 young Americans at risk. This callous decision isn’t just a betrayal of ‘DREAMers’ in North Carolina and across the country; it is a betrayal of the very idea of the American dream.  These young people were brought to our country without their consent and have known no other country as their own.  They are our neighbors, our classmates, our colleagues, and members of our Armed Services.  They pledge allegiance to our flag, pay our taxes, and contribute to our economy.   President Trump has said repeatedly that he would treat DREAMers with ‘great heart.’ While we have become accustomed to his broken promises, this may be his most heartless decision yet.   Make no mistake:  today’s announcement was driven entirely by cynical political calculations, not by any constitutional or legal requirement.  But now that the decision has been made, Congress must act to fix it.  In 2010, I voted with my colleagues in the House to pass the DREAM Act, only to see Senate Republicans defeat the measure. House leadership must bring the DREAM Act, or equivalent legislation, back to the floor for a vote without delay. We must protect these families from the anguish and suffering inflicted by the Trump Administration’s mass deportation agenda.

DREAMers are our neighbors, our classmates, our colleagues, and members of our Armed Services.  They pledge allegiance to our flag, pay our taxes, and contribute to our economy. In fact, DREAMers in North Carolina contribute more than $1.1 billion annually to the economy. The Trump Administration has put their futures in jeopardy, so I am urging my colleagues in Congress to immediately move to pass the #DREAMAct.  House Democrats House Republicans

Since January, I have held eight community listening sessions across the Fourth District to hear from you directly about your concerns and goals for our region, our state, and our country. As I return to Washington, I want you to know that I will fight for your interests, even in these unprecedented times. Here are some of the ways I plan to do that in the coming weeks.

This week, I joined a bipartisan amicus brief to the Supreme Court in a pending case that could stop the undemocratic, partisan gerrymandering of political districts in the United States. For too long, partisan gerrymandering has systematically stifled our democratic process, encouraging lawmakers to narrow their vision and curtailing their ability to reach common ground. I am proud to add my voice to this effort. FULL RELEASE:  https://go.usa.gov/xR6SF

ICYMI: I joined my fellow House Democrats to discuss the importance of immediately passing the #DREAMAct. DREAMers are our neighbors, our classmates, our colleagues, and members of our Armed Services. I want you to know that I will fight for you. House Democrats will fight for you. Continue to make your voices heard! (My remarks begin at 49:15)

Today, we pause to reflect on the lives lost in the terrorist attacks on September 11th. We also honor the heroic acts of the first responders and members of our armed services who answered the call for help. Together, the American people stood united in the face of hate as we worked to rebuild and heal. We will never forget.
I'm happy to join the USO this morning to help assemble care packages for service members supporting Hurricanes Irma and Hurricane Harvey relief.

DREAMers' contribution to the workforce and economy of North Carolina is indisputable. If Congress doesn't act to pass a #DREAMAct to protect these patriotic, young Americans, the North Carolina economy stands to lose an estimated $1.1 billion in annual GDP.

As a co-chair of the Congressional Humanities Caucus, I want to thank Lin-Manuel Miranda for being a champion for the National Endowment for the Humanities. His leadership and talent adds a powerful voice to the call for funding in the arts and humanities!

This Hispanic Heritage Month, I’m proud to join millions of Americans in honoring the history, culture, and achievements of our Latino communities. Let us reflect on the incredible role that our Latino communities have in our national story. And let us reaffirm our commitment to promoting opportunities in those communities for many years to come.

The American people have overwhelmingly rejected proposals to dismantle the Affordable Care Act. The Graham-Cassidy bill is nothing more than a last-ditch effort to resuscitate Trumpcare and deny insurance coverage to tens of millions of Americans. It must be rejected.

The Graham-Cassidy ACA repeal bill has had no hearings, no mark-ups, and no CBO score. Republicans in Congress are trying to push this Trumpcare bill through without knowing how much it costs or how many millions of Americans would lose coverage. Your advocacy in defense of the Affordable Care Act over the last eight months has been critical to defeating earlier versions of Trumpcare, we need your voice now more than ever. #ProtectOurCare

President Donald J. Trump's speech to the UN General Assembly served only to further alienate the U.S. from its allies, and to sow doubts among our adversaries as to our resolve. In an incoherent series of brash threats, the President called on the international community to ‘totally destroy’ a nuclear-armed North Korea, while undermining the international effort to restrain Iran’s nuclear program. The President’s hypocritical threats and childish name-calling do nothing to advance American interests or project American strength.
L'shanah Tovah to all celebrating Rosh Hashanah. May you have a happy and sweet New Year.

President Trump and Congressional Republicans are pushing ahead with a healthcare bill that would affect millions of Americans and one-sixth of the U.S. economy—all without a Congressional Budget Office score or anything resembling a public hearing process. The #GrahamCassidy bill has not received one endorsement from a major healthcare industry or advocacy group, and that’s for good reason. Take a look at how it would impact North Carolina in 2027 alone—and then make your voices heard to #ProtectOurCare.

The devastation we have seen this week in Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands is heartbreaking. Millions of American citizens are now without access to food, electricity, and potable water.  The Trump administration should act immediately to make Department of Defense and other additional resources available to aid in search-and-rescue, law enforcement, transportation, and medical assistance. In the immediate wake of a disaster of this scale, these resources could literally mean life or death for thousands of affected residents. Additionally, Congress should move to swiftly pass a comprehensive relief package that provides assistance for these American territories and addresses unmet need in Texas, Florida, North Carolina and other states still recovering from recent disasters.

ICYMI: As the conversation around climate change continues to be undermined by misleading scientific claims and partisan theatrics, it is more important than ever to encourage the flow of accurate, accessible information.This article from the New York Times Sunday edition is helpful in understanding how Earth’s climate has been damaged and what we can do a to slow its progress and mitigate its effects on our globe.

Today, Senator Tom Udall and I introduced the We The People Democracy Reform Act. This bicameral bill addresses a series of comprehensive democratic and electoral reforms to restore integrity, accountability, and transparency to our broken political system.  This legislation will comprehensively reform campaign finance laws, increase transparency and accountability in the political system, end extreme partisan gerrymandering, increase voter participation, and strengthen lobbying and revolving door laws. Check it out here → http://goo.gl/WxwhZ3

The American people have lost faith in their political system. Dark money, mega-donors, and foreign actors have plagued our democratic process and curtailed our ability to get things done on behalf of the American people. Additionally, the Trump White House has displayed serious, unprecedented conflicts of interest that need to be addressed. That's why I introduced the We the People Act with Senator Tom Udall to restore public confidence in our democratic institutions.

Today I joined North Carolina for Puerto Rico to help prepare relief packages for those devastated by #HurricaneMaria. Thank you to all who have donated or volunteered to assist our fellow Americans in need. #NC4PR

Last night, our country witnessed yet another senseless and despicable act of gun violence, this time at a concert in Las Vegas. Lisa and I join the American people in grieving with the families and loved ones of the more than 50 people who lost their lives and more than 400 wounded survivors of what we now know is the largest mass shooting in our nation’s modern history.   And yet we are well past the point where grieving is enough—we must summon the will and courage to take concrete action to prevent future tragedies. Anything short of that is a betrayal of the thousands of Americans who lose their lives each year to gun violence, and a betrayal of our values as a great nation.

Today, Congressman Ted Deutch and I sent a letter to Donald J. Trump urging him to re-certify the Iran Nuclear Agreement. For more than two years, the agreement has realized its objective of constraining Iran’s nuclear program to prevent a nuclear-armed Iran. Without ironclad evidence of Iranian violations of the agreement, withholding certification of the agreement would jeopardize our national security, harm our international relationships, and embolden Iran. We urge the President to heed the advice of his military and intelligence advisers rather than play politics with national security.

Our nation's budget is a moral document that should reflect our values and priorities for the future. The House Republican Budget abandons those values and sets the middle class up for failure. My full statement here:

Birth control is health care, it’s plain and simple. Today, President Trump rolled back a provision protecting birth control coverage, taking aim at the 62 million women that benefit from guaranteed no co-pay contraception. Birth control is not controversial - nearly 9 out of 10 women will use birth control at some point in their lives. This decision proves that President Trump does not understand women’s health.
This morning at 8:30am ET I'll be joining C-SPAN Washington Journal to discuss the importance of the #IranNuclearDeal Tune in! https://www.c-span.org/series/?washingtonJournal

My office is accepting applications from college students for Spring Internships in both my Raleigh, NC and Washington, DC Offices. Students can apply on my website: https://price.house.gov/kids-students/internships

This morning I joined C-SPAN Washington Journal to discuss why the Iran Nuclear Deal is vital to our national security interests and I urged Donald J. Trump not to decertify Iran's compliance with the agreement. Watch here: https://goo.gl/i6rHos

President Trump’s decision to decertify Iran’s compliance with the Iran Nuclear Deal threatens to alienate the U.S. from our allies and embolden the Iranian regime. Countless military and intelligence advisers—including the President’s own Secretaries of Defense and State—have affirmed Iran’s compliance with the agreement, but the President seems intent on appealing to his political base regardless of the facts and at the expense of our national security. Additionally, an attempt by the President or Congress to unilaterally renegotiate or terminate terms of this agreement through executive action or legislation would undercut our international partners and jeopardize diplomatic efforts to prevent a nuclear-armed Iran.    Time and time again, this President has demonstrated that he has no capacity or desire to lead on the domestic or international stage—from betraying DREAMers, to walking away from the hard-won Paris climate accords, to tweeting insults to all who challenge him. He threatens our reputation as a country that keeps its word and stands with its allies. Congress must now fill the gap, reaffirming our commitment to a non-nuclear Iran, solidarity with our allies, serious diplomacy, and leadership that inspires trust and confidence.

Since day one, President Trump has been determined to sabotage the health care system and strip millions of Americans of quality coverage.  The administration’s cruel decision to terminate cost-sharing reduction payments to insurers will result in Americans paying more money for worse health care coverage.    This follows other actions designed to undercut the Affordable Care Act (ACA), such as cutting advertising and outreach efforts, shortening the enrollment periods, and signing irresponsible executive orders.  President Trump has claimed that the ACA is “imploding” but the American people know better. This is a deliberate attempt to undermine the ACA and we must continue to keep our voices raised in opposition to these callous actions.

Our democracy is in trouble, as Donald Trump's presidency has thrown into sharp relief. Senator Tom Udall and I introduced the We the People Act last month as a framework for comprehensive democratic and electoral reform. The time has come to make our democracy democratic again. And now, no one can say that we lack ideas for how to do it. Check out this piece on our bill.

Today, House Republicans released a tax plan that raises taxes on millions of middle class families, slashes taxes for large corporations and the wealthiest earners, and adds more than $1.5 trillion to the national debt. Here is my full statement on the plan.

Under the Trump-Ryan tax plan, 443,000 North Carolina households making less than $82,510 a year would see a tax hike by 2027. The American people deserve real tax reform that puts the middle class first, not huge giveaways to corporations and the wealthy paid for by working families.

Under the Trump-Ryan tax plan, the cost of higher education will increase to pay for tax cuts for corporations and the wealthiest earners. In 2015, 12 million students used the student loan interest deduction targeted by this plan. I authored the provision restoring this deduction in 1997 to give students modest tax relief as the cost of college was rising. At a time when student loan debt is at an all-time high, we should be expanding these provisions, not borrowing from the future.

Last night, I hosted the 2017 Fourth District Congressional App Challenge Pitch Competition and Awards Ceremony at North Carolina State University’s Friday Institute for Educational Innovation. Their app will be displayed on the house.gov website and in the United States Capitol. Congratulations to all of the students coders that participated in the 2017 Congressional App Challenge, and thank you for helping to showcase the Research Triangle’s next generation of entrepreneurs and innovators.

Today, the House is expected to vote on H.R. 38, the Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act, which would force states to accept concealed carry gun permits from all other states, regardless of their training standards, background check system, or safety requirements. Make no mistake: this extreme GOP bill would make it easier to cross state lines with hidden loaded weapons, threatening local communities by making it harder for law enforcement to determine who is lawfully carrying a firearm. I call on my colleagues to reject this shameful proposal.

It unilaterally undermines prospects for a peaceful resolution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and recklessly endangers U.S., Israeli, and regional security.

The #MeToo movement has sparked an important conversation in our country about sexual harassment, discrimination, bullying and abuse. Those who are willing to share their story deserve to be heard, regardless of the influence or position of their alleged aggressor. President Trump is attempting to silence the voices of the 17 women who have come forward to accuse him of sexual misconduct. I'm proud to join the Democratic Women's Working Group in their call for a congressional investigation into the allegations against Donald J. Trump.

Despite overwhelming opposition, FCC Chairman Ajit Pai is moving forward to eliminate #NetNeutrality, undermining the principles of innovation, fairness and openness on the internet. Don't think this decision affects you? Without net neutrality, your broadband provider will be able to block websites, restrict services, or charge you premiums if you want to reach certain online content. To the thousands of constituents who have called, emailed or wrote me about this issue, I hear you. That's why, this week, I'll be joining over 70 of my colleagues in the House to demand that the FCC Chairman end this act of corporate welfare.

In the 5 years since 26 children and teachers were massacred at Sandy Hook, more than 50,000 people have lost their lives to gun violence in the United States. Despite the frequency of mass shootings and day-to-day violence on our streets, Congress has failed to confront this epidemic with even modest preventative measures. Astoundingly, Congress has instead taken a number of steps to exacerbate the problem. We know these tragedies are not inevitable, but as long as lawmakers are beholden to the gun lobby, I fear that our communities will continue to be exposed to senseless acts of violence and hate.

The partisan majority in the Federal Communications Commission has once again proven their commitment to corporate welfare, at the expense of the public interest. Despite overwhelming public opposition and a clearly corrupted comment process, the FCC, under the misguided leadership of Chairman Ajit Pai, has voted to eliminate #NetNeutrality, a decision that will erode the principles of openness, innovation, and fairness that are the cornerstone of the internet. This blatant corporate handout is yet another example of the Trump Administration’s anti-consumer agenda at work. Congress must act immediately to ensure the internet remain a free and open public platform.

Secretary Madeleine K. Albright and I agree: we have reached an "Article One moment" in our nation's history. From withdrawing from the most significant global climate agreement in history, to provoking a war of words with nuclear-armed North Korea, to disparaging the work of career diplomats and foreign policy experts, President Trump has fallen short of the mature and competent leadership required of the leader of the free world. Now more than ever, Congress must act to fill the void of diplomatic leadership expected of the most powerful nation in the world.

The GOP is pushing through a tax plan that raises taxes on 86 million middle class families and adds $1.5 trillion to the national debt. Hearing from 4th District constituents at home is a top priority. This year, I hosted 9 town hall meetings, attended 172 community events, and visited 17 area schools. If you would like me to visit your organization, please reach out to my office: https://priceforms.house.gov/forms/eventrequest/

Students: have an innovative app idea?   Join us for the second annual Congressional App Challenge Hackathon hosted by Congressman David Price (NC-04) and Congressman G. K. Butterfield (NC-01). Students that attend the Hackathon will have the opportunity to meet with mentors, complete an exercise in design thinking, and receive tips from public relations professionals on mastering a "pitch".  Students will have the opportunity to work in teams to start, develop, or complete an app for the challenge.   Please bring a laptop for the Hackathon. If you would like to participate, but do not have access to a laptop, please email Katelynn Anderson in Rep. Price's office at Katelynn.Anderson@mail.house.gov.   Lunch and snacks will be provided!   The winning app will be featured in an interactive display in the United States Capitol. Additionally, Amazon Web Services has announced that it is providing $250 in credits to the winning team to be used for cloud computing services to be split among the winners nationwide (with parental consent).  All participants will also be recognized by Congressman Price at a reception at the Friday Institute at NC State on Thursday, November 16.   Teachers and administrators will also be invited to attend.   Congressional App Challenge Background  The Congressional App Challenge is designed to promote STEM education by recognizing and incentivizing young talent to create a concept or source code for an online or mobile application (“app”).  Eligibility  Open to High School age students that attend school or live in the Fourth Congressional District or First Congressional District.  Students are only eligible to compete once they have signed up for the Challenge at CongressionalAppChallenge.us.  Students may only compete in one district.  Students may compete as individuals or in teams of up to four.  If competing as a team: at least two of the teammates must be eligible to compete within the district in which they are submitting.  There is no technical age minimum, but the App Challenge is intended for high school students.  Recent High School graduates are not eligible to compete.  Submission Requirements  Students must submit their apps by noon on November 1, 2017.  The app students create may cover any topic, but they must be original and appropriate.  List of Submission Requirements:  1. Sign-up Form. Students must fill out a sign-up form so their eligibility can be verified on congressionalappchallenge.us.  If students are competing as part of a team, the sign-up form must include the relevant information from each student  2. App Information. Students will be asked to answer a series of questions including: title of the app, the coding language used, what they were trying to accomplish and why, an explanation of a difficulty they faced in programming and how it was overcome, and what improvements the students would make  3. Demonstration Video. Students must create a 1 to no more than 3 minute video, post it on YouTube or Vimeo, and submit the link on the Congressional App Challenge submission form. The video must be set up to public view. Videos that are longer than 3 minutes will be penalized per the judges’ discretion.  Past winners can be found here, as well as their videos for inspiration.  4. Exit Questionnaire. The questionnaire will be emailed to students after final submission.  Judging   A local panel of judges will decide the winner of the App Challenge, and a reception will be held for all participants on Thursday, November 16 at NC State's Friday Institute. More information will be provided to students that submit an app.
